tit.e: Eiraku-tsuho (bronze coins struck in the Ming dynasty)
Eiraku-tsuho (bronze coins struck in the Ming dynasty)
Eiraku-tsuho (bronze coins struck in the Ming dynasty)

sen.j: 永楽通宝（えいらくつうほう）は、中国、明朝第3代皇帝・永楽帝の時代に作られた銭貨。
sen.e: Eiraku-tsuho is a coin minted during the reign of the 3rd emperor of the Ming dynasty, Yongle.
Eiraku-tsuho is a coin minted during the reign of the 3rd emperor of the Ming dynasty, Yongle.
Eiraku-tsuho is a coin minted during the reign of the 3rd emperor of the Ming dynasty, Yongle.

sen.j: 室町時代に日本へ大量に輸入され、江戸時代初頭まで流通し、永楽銭とよばれていた。
sen.e: A huge number of the coins were imported to Japan in Muromachi period and they were circulated in Japan up to the early Edo period, and they were called Eirakusen.
A huge number of the coins were imported into Japan during the Muromachi period and they were circulated in Japan up to the early Edo period, and were called Eirakusen.
A huge number of the coins were imported into Japan during the Muromachi period and they were called Eiraku-sen and distributed in Japan up to the early Edo period.

sen.j: 形状は、円形で中心部に正方形の穴が開けられ、表面には「永樂通寳」の文字が上下右左の順に刻印されている。
sen.e: The shape is round and at the center were square thirl is made, and on the surface of the coin were kanji characters "永樂通寳" which were coined from top to bottom and right to left in order.
sen.cmt: 漢字表記が必須と考え、左記の様にしました。
sen.e: The shape is round and at the center a square hole is made, and on the surface of the coin were kanji characters "永樂通寳" which are read from top to bottom and right to left.
The coin was round-shaped which has a square hole at the center, and on the surface were kanji characters '永樂通寳' which are read from top to bottom and right to left.

sen.j: 材質は銅製、貨幣価値は1文として通用したが、日本では天正年間より永楽通宝1枚が鐚銭4文分と等価とされた。
sen.e: The material is copper and circulated as the value1mon (a unit name and value of small money at the time), however in Japan, a piece of Eirakutsuho was valued equivalent to 4 mons of Bitasen (low quality coins whose surfaces were worn away) from Tensho years.

The material is copper and circulated as avalue of 1mon (a unit name and value of small money at the time), however in Japan, one Eirakutsuho coin was valued at 4 mons of Bitasen (low quality coins with surfaces worn away) from the Tensho years.

The coins were made of copper and circulated as a value of 1 mon (a unit name and value of small money at the time); however, in Japan one Eiraku-tsuho coin was valued at 4 mons of Bitasen (low quality coins with surfaces worn away) from the Tensho years.

sen.j: 慶長13年（1608年）には通用禁止令がだされ、やがて寛永通宝等の国産の銭に取って代わられた。
sen.e: In 1608, the ban on the circulation of Eirakusen was issued and Eirakutsuho was replaced with domestically minted coins such as Kanei-tsuho.
In 1608, a ban on the circulation of Eirakusen was issued and Eirakutsuho were replaced with domestically minted coins such as Kanei-tsuho.
In 1608, a ban on the circulation of Eiraku-sen was issued and Eiraku-tsuho were replaced with domestically minted coins such as Kanei-tsuho.
sen.cmt: Eirakusen→Eiraku-sen(文章中の用語統一)Eirakutsuho→Eiraku-tsuho(タイトルに合わせました)

sen.j: しかしその後も永という仮想通貨単位(すなわち永一貫文＝金一両であり1/1000両を表す)は残った。
sen.e: However, virtual monetary unit called Ei (Ei of Eiraku-tsuho) lasted i.e. Ikkanmon (weight of the coins and approximately equivalent to 1,000 mons of coins) of Ei equals to 1 ryo (a unit name of large sum of money) of gold coin, thus 1 Ei is 1/1000 ryo and this Ei account system was actually used for the collection of nengu (annual tax).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, the virtual monetary unit called Ei (Ei of Eiraku-tsuho) remained in place i.e. Ikkanmon (weight of the coins and approximately equivalent to 1,000 mon of coins) of Ei equals 1 ryo (a unit name for a large sum of money) of a gold coin, thus 1 Ei is 1/1000 ryo and this Ei account system was actually used for the collection of nengu (annual tax).

However, the virtual monetary unit called Ei (Ei of Eiraku-tsuho) remained in place; i.e., Ikkanmon (weight of the coins and approximately equivalent to 1,000 mon of coins) of Ei equaled 1 ryo (a unit name for a large sum of money) of a gold coin, thus 1 Ei was treated as 1/1000 ryo.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: この永勘定が年貢の取り立てに引き続き用いられた。
sen.e: This Ei account system actually continued to be used for the collection of nengu (annual tax).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: このように永楽通宝は、(日本の貨幣制度に)長く影響を残した（1永は4文前後）。
sen.e: Thus Eirakutsuho influenced the Japanese monetary system much and long (1 Ei was actually valued as equivalent to around 4 mons.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thus Eirakutsuho greatly influenced the Japanese monetary system over a long period of time (1 Ei was actually equivalent to around 4 mon.)
Thus Eiraku-tsuho greatly influenced the Japanese monetary system over a long period of time (1 Ei was actually equivalent to around 4 mon).
sen.cmt: Eirakutsuho→Eiraku-tsuho(タイトルに合わせました)ピリオドを）の後にしました。

sen.j: なお、永楽通宝は明では流通しておらず、もっぱら国外で流通していたと考えられている。
sen.e: It is thought that Eirakutsuho was not circulated in the territory of Ming dynasty and mainly used in outside of China.
It is thought that Eirakutsuho was not circulated in the territory of the Ming dynasty and was mainly used outside of China.
It is thought that Eiraku-tsuho was not circulated in the territory of the Ming and was mainly used overseas.

sen.j: 明では初代洪武帝のときに銭貨使用が禁じられ、すべて紙幣（後には銀錠）に切り替えられていた
sen.e: In the Ming dynasty, at the reign of the founder Emperor Kobu (Shu GENSHO), the use of metal coins were prohibited and all the money were switched to paper money (later, switched again to Ginjo (silver coins used in China until early in the 20th century).)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Ming dynasty, during the reign of the founder Emperor Kobu (Shu GENSHO), the use of metal coins was prohibited and all the money were switched to paper money (later, switched again to Ginjo - silver coins used in China until early in the 20th century)

In the Ming dynasty during the reign of the founder Emperor Kobu (Shu GENSHO), the use of metal coins was prohibited and all the money were switched to paper money (later switched again to Ginjo - silver coins used in China until early in the 20th century).

sen.j: （洪武帝は中国統一前には支配地域の一部で大中通宝「銅銭」を発行しており、統一後も洪武通宝「銅銭」を発行していた）。
sen.e: (Emperor Kobu also issued Daichu-tsuho (copper coin) in his own territory before he unified China, and after the unification, he also issued Kobu-tsuho (copper coin).)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: (Emperor Kobu also issued Daichu-tsuho (copper coins) in his own territory before he unified China, and after unification, he also issued Kobu-tsuho or copper coins.)
(Emperor Kobu also issued Daichu-tsuho 'copper coins' in a part of his own territory before he unified China; after the unification, he issued Kobu-tsuho 'copper coins.')
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正、「'」→「'」に修正、ピリオドの位置を移動

sen.j: 一方、日本では貨幣経済が急速に発展しており、中国銭貨への需要が非常に高まっていた。
sen.e: In the meantime in Japan, money economy has rapidly developed and the demands for Chinese coins increased very much.
In the meantime in Japan, the money economy had rapidly developed and the demands for Chinese coins greatly increased.
In the meantime, the money economy in Japan rapidly developed and the demands for Chinese coins greatly increased.

sen.j: そのため、日本との貿易決済用銭貨として永楽通宝が鋳造されることとなったのである。
sen.e: As a result in China, Eirakutsuho was minted as an instrument to settle the trade with Japan.
As a result in China, Eirakutsuho was minted as an instrument to settle the trade with Japan.
As a result in China, Eiraku-tsuho was minted as an instrument to settle the trade with Japan.
sen.cmt: Eirakutsuho→Eiraku-tsuho(タイトルに合わせました)

sen.j: 織田信長は、永楽通宝の旗印を用いている。
sen.e: Nobunaga ODA used Eirakutsuho as his oriflamme.
Nobunaga ODA used Eirakutsuho as his symbol.
Nobunaga ODA used Eiraku-tsuho as his symbol.
sen.cmt: Eirakutsuho→Eiraku-tsuho(タイトルに合わせました)

sen.j: 理由は明らかでないが、貨幣流通に早くから注目していたためであるとも言われる。
sen.e: The reason why he used it as oriflamme was not known, however, it is said that he foresightedly paid attention to the monetary economy.
The reason why he used it as his symbol was not known, however, it is said that with foresight he paid attention to the monetary economy.
The reason why he used it as his symbol was not known, however, it is said that with foresight he paid attention to the monetary economy.

sen.j: 永楽銭
sen.e: Eiraku-sen
Eiraku-sen
Eiraku-sen

sen.j: 平安時代から鎌倉時代にかけて日本国内の商業・物資流通が活発化すると共に貨幣の必要性が重用になっていった。
sen.e: As the commerce and physical distribution was activated from Heian to Kamakura period in Japan, the needs for money became important.
As commerce and physical distribution was activated from the Heian to the Kamakura period in Japan, the need for money became important.
As commerce and physical distribution was activated from the Heian to the Kamakura period in Japan, the need for money became important.

sen.j: しかしながらその時代には律令体制が崩壊しており、銭貨鋳造を行う役所も技術も廃れていた事から、中国から銅銭を輸入してそれを国内で流通させていた。
sen.e: However, because the Ritsuryo system already collapsed at the time and the office and technology to mint coins fell into disuse, they had to import copper coins from China and distribute them domestically.

However, because the Ritsuryo system already collapsed at the time and the office and technology to mint coins fell into disuse, they had to import copper coins from China and distribute them domestically.

However, because the Ritsuryo system had already collapsed at the time and the technology to mint coins as well as the office in charge fell into disuse, Japan had to import copper coins from China to distribute domestically.

sen.j: その中でも明の永楽帝の時代に永楽 (明)9年（1411年）から作られた銅銭永楽通宝（永楽銭）が、室町時代中期に大量に輸入された。
sen.e: Among them, copper coin Eiraku-tsuho (Eiraku-sen) minted from 1411 in the reign of Ming dynasty's Emperor Yongle were imported on a massive scale in the middle of Muromachi period.
Among them, the copper coin Eiraku-tsuho (Eiraku-sen) minted from 1411 in the reign of the Ming dynasty's Emperor Yongle were imported on a massive scale in the middle of the Muromachi period.
Among them, the copper coin Eiraku-tsuho (Eiraku-sen) minted from 1411 in the reign of the Ming dynasty's Emperor Yongle were imported on a massive scale in the middle of the Muromachi period.

sen.j: この多くは勘合貿易を通じて日本に持ち込まれたものである。
sen.e: Most of them were imported through the tally trade (between Japan and the Ming dynasty) to Japan.
Most of them were imported through the tally trade (between Japan and the Ming dynasty) to Japan.
Most of them were imported through the tally trade (between Japan and the Ming dynasty) to Japan.

sen.j: 永楽銭という用語は、明代に輸入された銅貨一般を差す場合もある。
sen.e: The term Eirakusen are sometime applied to all and general copper coins imported at the time of Ming dynasty.
The term Eirakusen are sometime applied to all and general copper coins imported at the time of the Ming dynasty.
The term Eiraku-sen is sometimes applied to all copper coins imported at the time of the Ming dynasty.

sen.j: 良質の銅銭で有ったため江戸初期まで基本貨幣として使われていた。
sen.e: The quality of the copper coins are good and were used as a key currency until the early Edo period.
The quality of the copper coins were good and were used as a key currency until the early Edo period.
The quality of the copper coins was good, and these coins were used as a key currency until the early Edo period.

sen.j: 民間が勝手に鋳造した銭貨を私鋳銭というが、中国江南や日本で作られた私鋳銭も多く流通していた。
sen.e: While the coins privately minted are called Shichusen (coinage cast by public), many shichusen minted in Konan (Kangnam) in China and Japan were also circulated.
While privately minted coins are called Shichusen (coinage cast by the public), many shichusen minted in Konan (Kangnam) in China and Japan were also circulated.
While privately minted coins are called Shichusen, many shichusen minted in Jiangnan in China and Japan were also circulated.
sen.cmt: (coinage cast by the public)は不要だと思います。(Kangnam)→(Jiangnan)中国の江南はJiangnanではないでしょうか。http://studyabroad.jiangnan.edu.cn/ja/folk.htmlこの場合、Konanも不要だと思います。

sen.j: しかし、これらの私鋳銭は粗悪で品質も悪かったため、鐚銭（ビタ銭）と呼ばれ、官鋳の永楽銭よりも低価値で流通していた。
sen.e: However, these shichusen were inferior in quality thus they were called bitasen and exchanged with lower value than government casting eirakusen.
However, these shichusen were inferior in quality thus they were called bitasen and exchanged with lower value than government casting eirakusen.
However, these shichusen were called bitasen for their inferior quality and exchanged at a lower value than government casting Eiraku-sen.

sen.j: この銅銭の品質の違いによる価値のばらつきは問題になっており、戦国時代 (日本)には戦国大名が良銭と悪銭の区別を禁ずる撰銭令を発出することもしばしば見られた。
sen.e: As the difference of value of the copper coins became problematic, sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period often issued ordinance of "Erizenirei",the ban on the selection of good quality currency, and not to differentiate the good coins and bad coins.

As the difference in the value of the copper coins became problematic, the sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period often issued ordinances concerning "Erizenirei,"banning the selection of good quality currency, and not to differentiate the good coins and bad coins.

As the difference in the value of the copper coins became a problem, the sengoku daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period often issued ordinances called Erizenirei, which banned differentiating the good coins and bad coins.

sen.j: 江戸時代に入ると江戸幕府が慶長11年（1606年）に独自の銅銭慶長通宝を鋳造して2年後には永楽銭の流通禁止令がだされた。
sen.e: When the time entered into Edo period, Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) cast their own Japanese copper coin, Keicho-tsuho in 1606, and 2 years later, the bakufu issued an ordinance to prohibit against the distribution of Eirakusen.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the Edo period, the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) cast their own Japanese copper coins, Keicho-tsuho in 1606, and 2 years later, the bakufu issued an ordinance to prohibit the distribution of Eirakusen.

The Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) began casting their own copper coins (called Keicho-tsuho) in the year 1606 of the Edo period; two years later, the bakufu issued an ordinance prohibiting the distribution of Eiraku-sen.

sen.j: この段階では慶長通宝の流通も充分でなく、実態は永楽銭の優位的通用を禁じ鐚銭並みの通用になったとされる。
sen.e: It is said that at this stage, the circulation of Keichotsuho was not sufficient enough, and the reality of the ordinance was to ban the superior position in circulation of Eirakusen, and as a result, the distribution of Eirakusen became the level of that of bitasen.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is said that at this stage, the circulation of Keichotsuho was not sufficient enough, and the reality of the ordinance was to ban the superior position in circulation of Eirakusen, and as a result, the distribution of Eirakusen became the same level as bitasen.

It is said that at this stage, the amount of Keicho-tsuho circulated was not sufficient enough, and the ban resulted in prohibiting the circulation of Eiraku-sen at a superior position and promoting the use of Eiraku-sen at the same level as bitasen.

sen.j: 元和偃武後の寛永13年（1636年）には寛永通宝を本格的に鋳造し、寛文年間以降、全国的に流通し始めると永楽銭は次第に駆逐されていった。
sen.e: The bakufu minted Kanei-tsuho (pronounced as kan-ei-tsuho) in earnest in 1636 after the Genna-Enbu (peace after Genna era), and when the new coins started to circulate in the entire country in and after Kanbun era (1661 ~ 1672), Eirakusen was gradually driven out.

The bakufu minted Kanei-tsuho (pronounced as kan-ei-tsuho) in earnest in 1636 after the Genna-Enbu (peace after Genna era), and when the new coins started to circulate in the entire country in and after Kanbun era (1661 ~ 1672), Eirakusen was gradually driven out.

After the Genna-Enbu (peace after Genna era) in 1636, the bakufu minted Kanei-tsuho (pronounced as kan-ei-tsuho) in earnest and Eiraku-sen was gradually driven out when the new coins started to circulate in the entire country in and after the Kanbun era (1661- 1672).

sen.j: 永楽通宝が主に流通していたのは、伊勢国・尾張国以東の東国である。
sen.e: The area where Eirakutsuho was mainly circulated was the Eastern Japan including Ise Province and Owari Province.
The area where Eirakutsuho was mainly circulated was the Eastern Japan including Ise Province and Owari Province.
The Eiraku-tsuho was mainly circulated in the Ise Province and Owari Province and eastward.

sen.j: 特に関東では、永楽通宝が基準通貨と位置づけられ、これを永高制ということもある。
sen.e: In particular in Kanto, Eirakutsuho was positioned as the key currency, and sometimes this is called Eidakasei (currency system based on Eirakutsuho)
In particular in Kanto, Eirakutsuho was positioned as the key currency, and sometimes this is called Eidakasei (currency system based on Eirakutsuho)
Particularly in Kanto, Eiraku-tsuho was regarded as the key currency, and in some cases this is called Eidakasei (currency system based on Eiraku-tsuho).

sen.j: 西国では宋銭など唐北宋時代の古銭が好まれ、16世紀に入るまであまり流通しなかった。
sen.e: In the Western Japan, people preferred old coins of the time of Tang dynasty and Northern Sung dynasty such as Sung currency, and Eirakutsuho was not much circulated before 16th Century.
In Western Japan, people preferred the old coins of the Tang and Northern Sung dynastys such as the Sung currency, and Eirakutsuho was not circulated very much before the 16th Century.
In Western Japan, people preferred using the old coins from the Tang and Northern Sung dynasties such as the Sung currency, and Eiraku-tsuho was not circulated very much until the 16th Century.
